summary: In 1963, rodeo cowboy Jack Twist (Jake Gyllenhaal) and ranch hand Ennis Del Mar (Heath Ledger) are hired by rancher Joe Aguirre (Randy Quaid) as sheep herders in Wyoming. One night on Brokeback Mountain, Jack makes a drunken pass at Ennis that is eventually reciprocated. Though Ennis marries his longtime sweetheart, Alma (Michelle Williams), and Jack marries a fellow rodeo rider (Anne Hathaway), the two men keep up their tortured and sporadic affair over the course of 20 years.

WITH "BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN," Ang Lee presents himself as a symbolist, a minimalist, and a lot more.

Based on Annie Proulx's Pulitzer-winning work, "Brokeback Mountain" is an apt label for Lee's masterpiece on how the lives of two cowboys—the tight-lipped Ennis del Mar and the rodeo-loving Jack Twist—are made meaningful and even tragic by their summer experience in the wild. In Brokeback Mountain, the two cowboys have their own Walden experience, or epiphanies—something that they will hold on to for the rest of their lives—but that later turns out to be against social conventions, a dilemma to resolve that it makes tragic heroes out of them.

AS A SYMBOLIST, Ang Lee shows so much by concealing many things. Ennis del Mar's restrained affectation for his friend Jack Twist with whom he shares a steamy summer in 1963 predominantly figures in the end as tragedy.

A plethora of symbols prevails in the masterpiece. First, the sheep being tended by the two cowboys are the juxtaposition for Ennis del Mar, one whose restraint and silence seems the most deafening to all the other characters. The meekness of the sheep being tended by the two main characters delineates Ennis' inability to articulate his own preference, living in an otherwise homophobic society. Like the sheep feasted on by the obscure [the unseen social ridicule] wolves, Ennis del Mar confines himself to avoid the stigma from his outward relationship with another man.

Second, the bloodied clothes—Ennis's long-sleeved shirts and Jack's denim jacket—spells the boys' distinctive bonding. When Ennis finds the clothes in Jack's room after his death—with Jack's denim covering Ennis's shirt—the viewer is told that Jack has indeed nurtured their friendship and union. Towards the end of the movie, after Ennis gets to know of Jack's fate through his wife Lorraine, Ennis's shirt is already covering Jack's clothes. The living already treasures the memory of the dead. Such cinematic contrivance affords us these symbols of male love and concern.

Also, the movie's title itself spells the polar tendencies and realities of the two main characters. While "Brokeback" spells their aggressive, masculine tendencies, "mountain" articulates their softer and more feminine sides, as they [get to] love each other.

"Brokeback" perhaps sounds contrived as it accounts for the harsh cowboy life that the Ennis and Jack encounter in the Wyoming ranch. The jobs they took on themselves literally "break" their backs. Yet, something else in the ranch does other things to them.

On the other hand, "mountain" speaks the providence of nature—in the way the camera portrays nature scenes as real-life postcards of lush vegetation, open fields and pristine panoramas of sky and water.

While their ranch work entails "breaking their backs" literally, the entire backdrop where they were makes them gentle to themselves.

AS A MINIMALIST, the Asian sensibility of Ang Lee surfaces in the film's sparse dialogues and its use of panoramic postcards-like shots. Lee's camera pans out to the poetic and the restrained.

The film zooms in on the ‘corked' anger and restraint in Ennis del Mar. Ennis del Mar's interesting character later turns out to be the more repressed, the wayward character who needs more redemption just because he cannot fully articulate himself—he thus becomes the disadvantaged protagonist, he is the tragic hero.

Lee's angles delineate well the characters. Ennis del Mar's displays the vacillation of a typical human being. While seeking to desire something else, he chooses to do otherwise. He then suffers greatly from not being able to articulate his feelings and aspirations which can get him something good.

Ennis del Mar sustains his inarticulateness through his murky relations with other characters. While he sustains himself as a father to Alma Jr., ironically he has already contradicted himself when he divorces his wife Alma.

While he maintains clandestine relations with his "fishing" friend Jack Twist, he suffers greatly from the inability to sustain any sensible one with a serious one. And while Ennis seeks to be conscious of social ridicule all the while—disregarding Jack's suggestion on cohabitation, he eventually suffers from the pain of it all when Jack finally gives it a go, and leaves him all alone.

When Jack Twist dies towards the end of the story, the dilemma of the protagonists is never resolved. The film then becomes an elegy for the death of love between two males—which—to society—means the death of the self simply because it cannot be, or can it?

Lee presents the audience the widest open spaces for introspection. When he captures the sprawling blue skyline and open waters and streams and fields, he tells them this is how wide the possibilities in the world are—where he lives, where everyone can etch their own notions on morality [or the lack of it].

With this, Lee presents to the audience the option to etch his own notion of right and wrong, his own sense of morality.

Lee presents wide, open spaces as he presents options for the human being to take a stand and articulate his convictions. While Jack Twist freely etches his own spectrum of colors in the open pages of Ennis' life, he is also easy and free to wheeze all these away. But everything he must have done was hinged on self-conviction, despite its not being grounded by the proper sense of right and wrong.

Meanwhile, the driftwood personality of Jack is clear to go against Ennis's sense of self, which later translates to a dilemma that shall challenge him from one moment onwards.

The film is brimming with binary opposites. And these are made clear when Jack Twist's life rifts from that of Ennis del Mar whose sensibility is all restraint and uncertainty.

Now acclaimed by a number of award-giving bodies, Ang Lee's "Brokeback Mountain" will certainly break the back of the moralists, despite the [degree of] sexual liberation prevalent in this country.

The film featuring boys loving boys is certainly a big "no-no"—something scowled upon by traditional social conventions in this only predominantly Catholic country in Asia.

But as lovelorn boys coming of age, characters Jack Twist and Ennis del Mar might hardly gain the ire of any viewer since they present two sincere characters whose dilemma of pursuing their preferences intersects harshly with social conventions.

Together they achieve sense of fulfillment—they fly like angels without wings. They become messengers of their own truths, speaking much of the reality that pervades among us.
Everyone has a Brokeback Mountain in their hearts, a dream that will never come true.

I was completely mesmerised by Brokeback Mountain. It is such a beautiful and poignant film, that also benefits from being gorgeously shot and adeptly acted and directed. The film does move slowly of course, but I personally think that Brokeback Mountain was deliberately paced like that(I said very similar things about 2001 and The Godfather too, they are constantly criticised for being boring yet both had their reasons for being paced like that). The slow pacing allowed us to empathise with the characters more, and that paid off, because the characterisations are superb. As are the beautifully written and thought-provoking screenplay and gentle scoring. Ang Lee's direction is the best it's been here I feel, while the cinematography and scenery are simply breathtaking. The acting is excellent. Heath Ledger I think gives his best performance here(sorry Dark Knight fans, I loved him there, but he was beyond amazing here), while Jake Gyllanhaal is very believable, and Michelle Williams is heart-wrenching. Also Brokeback Mountain is quite emotionally affecting, it really makes you think and the sheer beauty of the visuals, acting and story are enough to make me cry, and I was in pieces after the ending. In conclusion, a mesmerising film. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Should have been called 'Bareback Mountain'. The plot was not very believable, there were lots of slow, uneventful scenes, and the stupidity of the characters cannot be overstated. For example, the two main characters immediately kissed each other for ~15-20 seconds right in front of the door to the house with the wife inside, who promptly emerged. That and the frequency of outings and lack of talk should have led to some serious questioning and a much sooner divorce. There also wasn't a balance between the two main characters, the children could have played more of a role, and all the fighting was silly. However, the acting was solid, the cinematography and visual effects were pleasant, the sets/props/costumes looked the part, and the soundtrack was catchy.

One the most overrated films in this century. Why it was so interesting or sensational as late as 2005 is simply a mystery, or then maybe not. It shouldn't be provocative to anyone, in any sense, other than for being tedious and dull, but still it got attention as if the sexual liberty movement ending in the 1980's came back to have another bite. Perhaps it was how the positive critical response went hand in hand with some absurdly negative reactions from the Catholic Church and political conservatives, that made a snowball effect. This instantly lead to more media attention, and a debate that just had to grow to a box office success. Many more went to see what the fuzz was all about, and it further became political correct to give it good reviews and ratings, like some kind fashion, no matter what. Speaking of sheep, the issue with men having a romantic and sexual relationship in a film drama, even among cowboyish sheepherders, should really not be any immensly big deal in the new millennium, regardless of what the religious fanatics said. Other than that, the cinematography is nice with picturesque nature scenes combined with quite good acting performances, including innocent sex scenes and long sequences with no dialogue, generally nothing more than an average TV drama. Controversial? Absolutely not!

Brokeback Mountain is a movie that tells the story of two men in their 20s that fall in love with each other. The action takes place in the west of the US in the 1960s.

The acting from Jake and Heath was phenomenal and totally Oscar worthy, and Michelle Williams was also brutal. Anne Hathaway tough more subtle also portraid Jack's wife in a really great way.

The cinematography contrasted beautifully with the sense of claustrophobia that we always felt from Ennis and Jack relationship. The empty and melancholic eyes paired with the amazing landscape shots were enough to make a tough man cry.

The dialogue, tough simple, was unique and beautiful. The fact that they never really say "Love you" to each other helps humanizing the story and showing that true love is actually much more than words. True love is having to travel 14 hours every time you want to see your loved one, true love is when it hurts because you haven't seen that person in a really long time.

Obviously the directing is also brilliant and Ang Lee really does an incredible job in taking this story to the big screens.

The way this movies plays with toxic masculinity and constantly makes us question ''what it is to be a man?'' is just admirable and it is to be praised the way the music, the acting, the cinematography all combined together creating deep simbolisms and beautifull realistic scenes.

This 2005 romantic film is the acclaimed masterpiece of Taiwanese director Ang Lee. Brokeback Mountain was the loser of arguably the most controversial Oscar decision of all time when it was defeated by Crash in the Best Picture race. The shock was deep because this film told the heartbreaking story of same-sex lovers Ennis and Jack, finally addressing the taboo subject of homosexuality in Hollywood at the time.

Heath Ledger (Ennis) and Jake Gyllenhaal (Jack) embody the two protagonists in their breakthrough roles. The now deceased Ledger and Gyllenhaal were very good friends in real life, which visibly benefits their chemistry in the film. As individuals, they could hardly be more different. On the one hand, there is the introverted and taciturn cowboy Ennis, who gets to know himself better through his relationship with Jack, which he doesn't always like. He finds it difficult to show feelings and to fully engage with his co-cowboy. Jack, on the other hand, is a slightly eccentric rodeo rider, but also highly sensitive. He knows what he wants from the start and tries to make this clear to Ennis. However, his insecurity gets in the way of Jack's happiness, which is why his further path is rocky. Every time Ledger and Gyllenhaal share the screen together, there is a subtle but exuberant mood, laced with big emotions, feelings of happiness and a lot of frustration. The two give their all in these highly complex roles and deliver enormously human and passionate performances. In their separate, different lives, they are joined by strong female supporting roles. Michelle Williams as Ennis' wife Alma and Anne Hathaway as Jack's lover Laureen are also victims of a love that doesn't want to be, where Williams in particular acts very vulnerably.

In addition to the performances, Ang Lee's grandiose direction deserves special mention. Brokeback Mountain inspires with beautiful landscape images from the mountains that reflect the emotional worlds of the protagonists. When they return to the Brokebacks together, everything is colourful and idyllic, while in their private lives in the city, much seems dark and dreary. This arty component puts its stamp on the film and sends important messages. The score is also beautiful and gives you constant goosebumps. As artistic and real as Brokeback Mountain is, it is definitely not light fare. The story of two men who love each other more than anything, but are prevented from doing so by society, is hard to watch. The ending is more than borderline. The closeness to reality is both the great strength and weakness of Brokeback Mountain. The brutality towards animals is also exaggerated, even if it was a sad matter of course in the world of cowboys. However, if you love films that do something to you, this is the one.

Using its cinematography to catch our attention, we enter into some deep topics about homosexuality. The two main characters are immersed in problems related to the outside world and their true feelings. We know the difficult situation they're going through. What I was not completely happy with was the duration of the film, because it added subplots that made the movie too long, although they might have been necessary.

I went into Brokeback Mountain with a couple of assumptions - 1) that the film I filed in my head as the "gay cowboy movie" that my conservative parents wouldn't give any airtime to was old school 1800s cowboys, and 2) that it followed a relatively traditional forbidden love storyline and ended up as a critical darling because it happened to include a gay storyline. I was proven wrong on both counts. Brokeback Mountain gave hints initially of just being an adaptation of a conventional romance novel, but ended up being so much more; the film is a terribly morose take on repression, dishonesty, passion, and social norms that manages to hit you hardest with brief moments that punctuate a consistent, morose tone (the result of a univeral repression?), whether they be happy or devastating. What's more, the film doesn't let the most prominent aspect of its storyline (the homosexual relationship between the protagonists) define the film. Both Ennis and Jack have their own very human flaws that draw them into conflict just as often as the nature of their romance (if not more so), and these conflicts are critical features of the narrative. Ledger, Gyllenhaal, and Williams with her particularly unfortunate role are each fantastic. The fact that Crash took Best Picture in a year that this film was in competition is a miscarriage of justice, and that's not only because Crash is god-awful. Just an odd phenomenon - the male actors at virtually every level of importance in this film ended up becoming far more prominent than their female counterparts, with Ledger, Gyllenhaal, and even Harbour receiving much higher profile future roles than the then-popular Hathaway, Faris, and Mara; Williams is the only one to really buck this trend. (4.5/5)

In one of the most controversial upsets of all time the laughable race relations parable Crash (2005) won the Best Picture Academy Award over the acclaimed romantic drama that would serve as one of the first mainstream representations of homosexual love on screen. I was outraged, having seen both of the films, that the markedly lesser production triumphed as it was sad that they could not pick up on a film that would develop so much cultural cache over the following years. While 2005 was a weak year for film overall this movie was fully deserving of it's nomination and I would have less vitriol for the 2005 Best Picture lineup had this film been honored.

Cowboys Jack Twist, Jake Gyllenhaal, and Ennis Del Mar, Heath Ledger, fall in love in 1963 while herding sheep together. They separate for four years after they finish herding the sheep as Del Mar is uncomfortable about engaging in a homosexual relationship due to a traumatic event he witnessed as a child. The men reconnect four years later and pretend to be fishing several times a year so that they can meet up and sleep together. Del Mar marries longtime girlfriend Alma Beers, Michelle Williams, who discovers their affair and later divorces her husband to marry the more attentive Monroe, Scott Michael Campbell. Twist marries the wealthy Lureen Newsome, Anne Hathaway, while having trysts with male prostitutes in Mexico. The two grow frustrated with the state of their relationship as Twist wants them to be together on a more permanent basis while Del Mar remains emotionally conflicted. After Twist's death Del Mar comes to terms with his own feelings and is able to mourn the loss of the love of his life.

By today's standards, just fourteen years later, the film's portrayal of gay love, almost sexless and emotionally torturous, seems rather conservative but at the time this was groundbreaking stuff. Sure, all of this content had been covered before in independent and foreign films but for the masses this was the first real exposure to a film of this sort from a respected director and a talented cast. I was struck by the fact that while the film is squeamish about addressing the physical elements of the relationship between the two men it does not shy away from broaching the topic of bisexuality. We see that Del Mar in some way enjoys sleeping with women but that emotionally only Twist can fulfill him while Twist is most likely homosexual as his sexual relationship with Lureen is fraught. In the age of there being a million different sexual orientations that people can identify themselves as the film appears remarkably forward thinking.

The movie also benefits from some very strong performances from it's two leads who are able to convey intense emotional turmoil through gazes and small gestures instead of long monologues. These are men who do not speak like the metropolitan, classy characters who would usually be the focus of a Hollywood romance and having them speak that way would take us out of the situation. We feel their pain in the silence and Gyllenhaal in particular excels at expressing latent desire in the early moments of the film with his desperate attempts to connect to his lover later in the film seeming all the more powerful for it. Williams and Hathaway also do great things with smaller parts as Hathaway in particular makes her part more than it appears on the stage. The fragility hiding behind her confident, wealthy façade is revealed when she asks Twist whether she is "Too fast" and Hathaway gets the frustration of a woman who has been told to be a certain way her entire life perfectly. While I can see why Williams earned the Academy Award nomination, she gives the showier performance, I think that Hathaway was more deserving of recognition.

People are right to be upset about this film not winning Best Picture because it is a beautiful piece of filmmaking despite some of the limitations it places on the relationship it depicts. People are still watching and enjoying this film fourteen years later which is a testament to it's power. After all, Good Night, and Good Luck (2005) is hardly a staple on television nowadays.

Ang Lee's Brokeback Mountain (2005) is a stunning tale of forbidden love brought to life by two of the greatest actors ever. Heath Ledger's perfect accent and gravelly voice tremble with an inner turmoil over his feelings in one of Heath's best performances. Jake Gyllenhaal is outstanding as the sensitive gay lover wishing for a better, open, and honest love life like he deserves. Both Ledger and Gyllenhaal deliver incredibly subtle and nuanced portrayals that I found deeply moving. Brokeback Mountain is a romantic tragedy and gripping drama for any audience to appreciate. 

Lee's direction is awe inspiring from the gorgeous natural scenery to his clever framing of these two lovers. His recreation of an older era and its biases is impressive on its own, but Lee breathes a passion for filmmaking with every shot. Take any frame of Brokeback Mountain and you will see a perfect image. Lee's tender and affectionate hand gives the camera a respectful and understanding perspective for the lead's homosexual encounters. Lee's direction is immaculate and thoughtful leading to pensive sequences of honest dialogue from Larry McMurty and Diana Ossana's touching script.

Brokeback Mountain is as much a journey of self discovery as it is a lens into the lives of two Southern men and their respective areas. Lee shines a light on homophobia and ignorance with a scathing critique of intolerance. As much as Lee uses Brokeback Mountain to show support for the homosexual community and a decent sympathy for the hurt spouses of the characters. Brokeback Mountain is well balanced between the sweet and uncertain romance and the tumultuous domestic life dramatic tension.

I adored Michelle Williams in Brokeback Mountain as much as the dual leading men. She is so expressive and heartbreaking with all her choices. She uses a visual pain to display a hurt knowledge her character possesses without ever having to say what she knows out loud. Williams gives a powerful performance and one of her most poignant as an actress.

Overall, Brokeback Mountain is misunderstood as a film. It does not deserve to be written off as the "gay cowboy movie," but should be appreciated for its careful plotting and brave depiction of gay love on a deeper level. You really come to understand how these two men feel and how they feelings hurt those around them, while making themselves miserable for being away from one another. The moving acting from Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal are two for the ages!

I’ve heard so much about Brokeback Mountain since it came out, because it was in the cultural zeitgeist to such a level that you couldn’t avoid hearing about it. So I had a lot of expectations when I sat down to watch it. I expected it to be bold about presenting the homosexuality of its characters, I expected it to have some powerful acting performances, and I expected it to have the line “I wish I knew how to quit you.” What I never expected in a million years was that I would find it so boring. Yes, it is a movie that gives an honest and heartfelt presentation of two men who love each other in a time when that love was forbidden. But that’s about all it does. The plot is no more involved than that, and moves at a frustratingly slow pace. I wanted things to happen, but the movie wanted me to wait for another 30 minutes before the next thing would happen. I couldn’t believe how many years were passing by in the story, and yet these are the moments we needed to stop and see? There were so many stops along the way that felt pointless or superfluous. Also, the attempt to show the aging of the actors was atrocious. I almost started to laugh out loud when Kate Mara showed up and was supposed to be Ledger’s daughter even though she clearly is around the same age as him. One thing that doesn’t help with my boredom was the fact that the dialogue is sparse throughout so much of Brokeback Mountain. There are a lot of silent moments, and when people talk there’s a lot of mumbling (particularly from Heath Ledger.) But aside from the delivery of some of the accents, I thought the acting was solid. The cast is stacked with some of the best actors working today, and they all deliver as best they can with this dialogue. But, there was one big problem...I didn’t feel any chemistry between Ledger and Gyllenhaal. The delivery of the dialogue and certain scenes when they were apart convinced me they were in love with someone, but their interactions together never sold me on the fact that they were in love with each other. I also started to get annoyed with the illogical way people acted in the film. For a time and place where everyone is painfully aware of how bigoted and intolerant people are of homosexuality, I cannot comprehend how careless characters are in this film about flaunting it. This was a relatively minor issue for me, because at least at those moments they were doing something. I have to reiterate that, more than anything, I was completely bored by Brokeback Mountain. It’s a subject that I find compelling, but I need more plot to make it work for me.

It's a tragedy.  It's a love story.  It's a tragic love story.  Of course it is, because it is about two cowboys in the 1960s who have a passionate affair one summer alone on the titular mountain in Wyoming.  The affair itself with its beautifully filmed scenic backdrop is delicately handled by director Ang Lee (but not without some visceral moments); however, it is the decades long aftermath that is really the focus of the picture.  Heath Ledger gives a truly exceptional performance as Ennis Del Mar, a man of few words but with strong and deep emotions restrained inside him. Jake Gyllenhaal is Jack Twist, a rodeo bull-rider, who seems weaker than Del Mar but more willing to take risks for love, despite society's prejudice.  After their initial time together, life takes them into the conventional roles for men in that decade - husband (to Michelle Williams and Anne Hathaway, respectively) and father (to two girls and one boy, respectively).  The screenplay (by Larry McMurtry and Dianna Ossana from a story by Annie Proulx) conveys the pain that both men feel in these relationships that do not offer them true love.  And the consequences play out much as you can expect, sadly.  Although this is an expensive prestige picture, and perhaps too safe and polished at times, the acting (particularly by Ledger) contributes to a moving (and crushing) feature that reminds us how far (and yet sometimes not so far) we have come in our journey as a society.

It not only leaves a lasting personal attachment with the characters but it includes beautiful cinematography that gives the audience a sense of awe and wonder. Yet sadly, this treasured film has been characterized as nothing but the "gay cowboy movie". This label is not only homophobic and ignorant, but it summarizes only a small portion of what the purpose and plot of the film is. Even the great Heath Ledger found this to be true when he said "people are very quick in life to label things that make them uncomfortable" and that it "transcends a label". He continues to say that the films purpose of the film is to show to how heterosexual and homosexual relationships are just the way two human souls love each other and that love is strong and pure no matter which gender they are. I found this to be extremely true that the theme of Brokeback Mountain is beyond sexuality which seems to surprise most viewers. Ang Lee did a perfect job showing the audience that any form of love is deserving of marriage and who are we to decide whether two human and adult people should or should not be together.

Brokeback Mountain can drag at times like most Westerns and romantic dramas, but its heartfelt story combines with Ang Lee's direction and its two leads make this an absorbing and memorable love story.

The chemistry between Gyllenhaal and Ledger, as well as their characters, was phenomenal. I absolutely loved how well the story played out. Everyone played their roles quite well (as expected from an Ang Lee film), and the climactic scene was an absolute thrill. I don't watch a lot of movies, but I'm glad I watched this one.

Well if there isn't a more diverse director than Ang Lee, maybe the only director who's films vary more would be Richard Linklater, (A Scanner Darkly, Boyhood, Dazed and Confused, School of Rock) or the late great Stanley Kubrick, (The Shining, 2001: A Space Odyssey, Full Metal Jacket). After the overblown, over serious mess of Hulk, Ang Lee has a go at another incredibly serious and incredibly worthy effort in Brokeback Mountain, just on a much lower budget. This time instead of subverting the action comic book movie Ang Lee has a go at subverting the equally serious and bravado filled genre of the western. Y'know I want Ang Lee to go off and make a stoner comedy. See how he likes that. 

Based on the eponymous short story by Annie Proulx, Brokeback Mountain follows the forbidden love of two gay cowboys and how they have to suppress their love in order to live. It stars Jake Gyllenhaal, (Donnie Darko, Nightcrawler, Zodiac) and Heath Leger, (The Dark Knight, 10 Things I Hate About You) as the gay cowboys amid a fine supporting cast that includes Anne Hathaway, Kate Mara, and David Harbour. It was actually quite entertaining to see people who have since gone on to bigger and better roles and think 'oh that went on to do that thing, like House of Cards,  Stranger Things, and um... Fantastic Four'. 

The real star of this film though is Ang Lee. His auterial fingers are all over this one. It's got the same trade mark sort of natural beauty and landscape poetry that we saw in things like Life of Pi and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and it's got the kind of worthy, sedentary pace we've come to expect from him, as well as the sort of outsider's eye to american genres that he's shown in other works. Aside from that it's clearly a very technically minded and stylish film, and technically it is very well made. Ang Lee wanted to show off and he did, but in a way that's also the problem. There is a degree of detachment to this film that stops you getting really emotionally involved. Watching it, I feel one removed from what's happening on screen in front of me. Now, to take a film like Drive, that's a film with a plot that wouldn't necessarily have you emotionally involved, but the high professionals sheen and style serves to get you involved. Whereas I feel in this film the high style of it only served to detach me from a story that I would otherwise naturally be emotionally involved in. It is a very involving story, and I did feel for the characters, (Heath Leger in the leading role truly shines in a very understated performance, died too young), but at the same time I felt like an outsider looking in, very much like Ang Lee himself is, instead of being truly into the story. There's something about how wiggy is is, something about the performances in some roles that doesn't quite gel. I would have preferred Ang Lee to focus on the essentials that convince you of the world instead of how to capture a nice shot, or the hair and make up for the period setting. 

I feel like now I need to talk about Jake Gyllenhaal. His has this underlying creepiness, this sort of gaunt visage that he played perfectly in Nightcrawler, but here, he's kind of miscast as the live wire romantic of the couple. He comes across as disingenuous and his liveliness is honestly more irritating because he just doesn't make it seem natural.

In the end Brokeback Mountain is a very solid film, but it lacks the emotional involvement to elevate it to something great.
